name: NPR
text: Administrators at Brigham Young University's campus say they are "deeply troubled" by reports that students may have intentionally tried to contract COVID-19, lured by blood donation centers that are paying a premium for plasma with COVID-19 antibodies. https://t.co/SNmIF5v2Ed

name: NPR
text:
Portugal's forward Cristiano Ronaldo, one of the world's most famous athletes, tested positive for the coronavirus. He "is doing well, without symptoms, and in isolation," the country's soccer federation said.
https://t.co/QTZwIzsYZT

name: NPR
text:
More than $1 billion has now been spent on TV ads for the 2020 presidential election in just 13 states — with most of that money being spent by Biden's campaign and groups supporting him.

Here's a state-by-state breakdown.
https://t.co/LVj8zNXhGF

name: NPR
text:
The no compromise movement didn't begin with the Dorr brothers. Our reporters track the tangled history of the message. 

This weeks episode looks at the intersection of racism and the no-compromise gun rights movement. https://t.co/q5ujEednQH

name: NPR
text:
Apple has announced the iPhone 12 — the first 5G-enabled iPhone that will eventually let data flow at speeds 10 to 20 times faster than 4G. But 5G infrastructure is years away from being widely available.
https://t.co/KL795UDCTu

name: NPR
text:
Amy Coney Barrett declined to address whether she believes President Trump can pardon himself, calling it a matter that could come before the Supreme Court after she is confirmed.
https://t.co/J8uDJT98rY
